captions.text:
Time travel can be complicated - and complicating,
so let's ignore all the paradoxical stuff

and talk about a few simple ways that you
can time travel without leaving your home.
First,

1) Do nothing - you're already traveling through
time! I mean, here you are - fifteen seconds

into the future since the start of this video!
Easy, huh? The point is, we're all always

traveling forwards through time. But that's
boring time travel. What's interesting is

time travel relative to other people. To do
that...

2) Start walking, and you'll travel through
time relative to someone standing still! We've

known for over a century that time and space
are really just two components of a single

"spacetime", and the faster you move, the
slower time will pass for you. If you take

a walk around the block, you'll be 3 femtoseconds
younger than your friend who stayed home.

Except, in order to walk around the block,
you had to...

3) Stand up. You're now further from the Earth,
and so gravity is a tiny bit weaker for you.

Which means you've traveled through time relative
to your friend who's sitting down. That's

right, more gravity makes time slow down,
too. If you stand up for a minute your feet

will have aged 10 femtoseconds less than your
head. On the other hand, GPS satellites high

in orbit experience less of earth's gravity
and thus travel noticeably faster through

time than we do, which is why their clocks
are calibrated to run slow.

But maybe you want to time travel more than
a few femtoseconds. Get ready for your head
to start spinning - I mean, the universe.

4) Because if the whole universe were spinning
really fast, general relativity predicts there

would be time-loops all over the place. Moving
along one of these loops, you'd always feel

like you were moving forwards in time, but
overall you'd loop around and travel back

to a time and place in your own past. It's
a little like how you can keep moving forwards

on the Earth, but Earth's curvature brings
you back to where you started.

Unfortunately, our universe isn't spinning.
Maybe it would be easier to build...

5) An infinitely long, super-dense spinning
cylinder, which would also curve space-time

enough to create a time-loop. The problem,
of course, is how do you build something that's

infinite in size? Maybe you could just make
it really really really big? MmmNo. If you

tried to squeeze this time machine into finite
space, you'd need negative energy - something

nobody knows how to create - to make it work.
Otherwise you'd end up with a black hole.

Wait, but what if instead of a black hole,
we...

6) Built a wormhole? Wormholes are hypothetical
(but not physically impossible) bridges through

space-time, shortcuts that can instantaneously
connect two different places and times in

our universe. If you had a wormhole you might
be able to use it to travel into the past
or the future.

The problem is that no-one knows how to build
a wormhole. Or, once you've built it, how

to keep it from collapsing: as Sean Carroll
has eloquently written, "keeping wormholes

open requires a form of negative energies.
Nobody knows how to make negative energies,

although they occasionally slap the name "exotic
matter" on the concept and pretend it might
exist."

Well that's too bad... but as consolation,
welcome to the future! Almost three minutes

have passed since the beginning of this video,
and we have personal jet-packs now!

title: 3 Simple Ways to Time Travel (& 3 Complicated Ones)

comments.text:
Most physicists used to think that when information enters a black hole it 
is lost, or possibly can reappear somewhere else. Hence the wormhole.
However, it is now the general consensus that the information doesn't go 
anywhere, and is actually returned to space in a higher-entropy state when 
the black hole evaporates.
My point is that the idea of the wormhole is pretty much not considered an 
option anymore.
Reference to the book "The Black Hole War" by Leonard Susskind.﻿

comments.author: Pillow Force

comments.text:
+Randy Perkins Hawking's "theory" is called:

"Chronology protection conjecture"

Definition of "conjecture" 

An *opinion* or conclusion formed on the basis of incomplete information.

Definition of "Theory" (the scientific definition)

"A scientific theory is a well-substantiated explanation of some aspect of 
the natural world that is acquired through the scientific method and 
repeatedly tested and confirmed through observation and experimentation." 

conjecture =/= theory

Definition of a Scientific law

"A scientific law is a description of a natural phenomenon or principle 
that invariably holds true under specific conditions and will occur under 
certain circumstances." (some rule [often an equation] that always holds 
true in known observation but no explanation is necessary)

"Chronology protection conjecture" is not a scientific theory or law. It's 
written as a conclusion so it isn't a hypothesis either. The best way to 
define it is as conjecture. Conjecture is useful and found all over the 
scientific world BUT it doesn't have the rigor of theories or laws.

The layperson's definition of "theorizing" is often one of the following: 
brainstorming, hypothesizing, or conjecturing.

Brainstorming is informally finding an explanation, hypothesizing is coming 
up with an explanation you're going to test (before publishing anything), 
and conjecture is a guess (often published) based in part on personal 
opinion and/or incomplete information.

Hawking is guessing (although educated) and he knows it. No one has enough 
information to form any scientific conclusions on this matter.

comments.author: dutchrjen

comments.text:
+dutchrjen wormholes are not theoretically possible due to the radioactive 
feedback that would make it collapse on itself. (although that is a theory 
as well)

 Incorporating quantum effects into general relativity indicate that 
virtual particles would pile up on themselves, driving the density of the 
energy so high it would collapse before any information could pass through 
the worm hole. This also keeps in line with the chronology protection 
conjecture. (time travel only being possible on the submicroscopic scales)
comments.author: Randy Perkins

comments.text:
+This statement is false Many methods of time travel to the past only allow 
one to travel back at most to when the time machine was created. Wormholes 
for example would have both ends created then one end would be shot off on 
a spaceship where time is moving slower. It would fly around for awhile at 
a high speed then it would be brought back.

Going through the wormhole would take you to the past but not to a point 
before both sides of the wormhole were created. Cosmic strings or spinning 
universes would do the same thing. 


Not saying time travel to the past is possible but if one could make a time 
machine most known methods would be limited with how far back you could go.

Time travel is simply impossible because time is a human idea, not the 
nature of the universe. We perceive "time" as motion and give it a name. 
When a spaceship is moving very extremely quickly, the things on it move 
slower, that is all. "Time" wouldn't slow down because it does not by 
itself exist, it is merely a special name we give to the motions we 
associate with time﻿

comments.author: Joris QC

comments.text:
It's the Schwarzschild radius. If you were to think of a point mass, the 
Schwarzschild radius for the point mass is the distance from the point at 
which the escape velocity is the speed of light. The formula is Rs=2GM/c^2 
where G is the gravitational constant (6.67E-11 Nm^2/kg^2), M is the mass 
of the object, and c is the speed of light (299792458 m/s). For most 
objects, it is very small relative to the size of the object, but if 
something were to be compressed to a size smaller than the Schwarzschild 
radius, it would form a black hole.

years, earth advances several decades. (O_o)﻿

comments.author: The Redstone Chicken

comments.text:
This is just a question, but wouldn't wormholes trample on general 
relativity? You are moving through space faster than light whilst barely 
moving at all and you may temporarily be occupying 2 points in space at the 
same time.

The only logical approach I can see is to close one end of the wormhole 
while inside of it before opening the other end; in which case it's not 
really a wormhole, it's more like stepping into a rift in space that's 
outside of space and time, with no clue as to when or where you'll come 
out. That's actually a lot like how the Tardis in Dr.Who works now that I 
think about it...﻿

comments.author: Paul Heller

comments.text:
QUESTION:
Okay so I have a question that might blow some minds like it did in my 
science class. can you really change history? I mean, if you go back in 
time and kill Hitler, and go back forwards in time, wouldn't everything 
change? well, wouldn't it kind of not? I mean, if you can go to the future 
and be in the same time period as your future self, wouldn't that mean that 
instead of being just you going through time individually, that its more 
like different 'you's going through time? so when you kill Hitler, going to 
the future nothing would've changed, being as your 'future self' has 
already done that, and you being your future self's past self, are just now 
going through an experience that has already happened, just not for you 
right now? and that your past self will do the same thing later on? think 
about it...﻿
